definitions.dating_raw: Attested from around (1350 to 1470) until the late 17 century.

definitions.definition: The quality or state of being able; capacity to do or of doing something; having the necessary power.
examples: This phone has the ability to have its software upgraded wirelessly.
This wood has the ability to fight off insects, fungus, and mold for a considerable time.

definitions.dating_raw: First attested in the mid 17 century.
First attested in the early 16 century.

definitions.definition: A unique power of the mind; a faculty.
definitions.dating_raw: First attested in the late 16 century.

definitions.definition: A skill or competence in doing; mental power; talent; aptitude .
examples: They are persons of ability , who will go far in life.
She has an uncanny ability to defuse conflict.
definitions.dating_raw: First attested in the early 17 century.

main_definition: ( obsolete ) Suitableness. [Attested from around (1350 to 1470) until the late 17 century.]
secondary_definitions: ( uncountable ) The quality or state of being able; capacity to do or of doing something; having the necessary power. [First attested from around (1350 to 1470).]
The legal wherewithal to act. [First attested in the mid 17 century.]
( now limited to Scotland dialects ) Physical power. [First attested from around (1350 to 1470).]
( archaic ) Financial ability. [First attested in the early 16 century.]
( uncountable ) A unique power of the mind; a faculty. [First attested in the late 16 century.]
( countable ) A skill or competence in doing; mental power; talent; aptitude . [First attested in the early 17 century.]
